# Implementation Tasks: Digital Twin Simulation (Gazebo & Unity)

**Feature**: Module 2: The Digital Twin (Gazebo & Unity)
**Branch**: `001-digital-twin-sim`
**Date**: 2025-01-01
**Status**: Generated by `/sp.tasks`
**Input**: Feature specification from `/specs/001-digital-twin-sim/spec.md`

## Summary

Create a comprehensive Docusaurus module for digital twin simulation using Gazebo and Unity, covering physics simulation, high-fidelity rendering, and sensor simulation. The implementation will include structured chapters as .md files organized for easy navigation, targeting AI students and developers learning physics simulation and environment building.

## Implementation Strategy

- **MVP Scope**: Complete User Story 1 (Physics Simulation in Gazebo) with basic examples and navigation
- **Delivery Approach**: Incremental delivery with each user story as an independently testable increment
- **Testing**: Verify Docusaurus build and navigation after each phase

## Dependencies

- User Story 1 (P1) must be completed before User Story 2 (P2)
- User Story 2 (P2) must be completed before User Story 3 (P3)
- Foundational tasks must be completed before any user story tasks

## Parallel Execution Examples

- Within each user story: Content creation can be parallelized with navigation updates
- Documentation for different sensor types in US3 can be developed in parallel

## Phase 1: Setup Tasks

### Project Initialization

- [x] T001 Create module directory structure at frontend-book/docs/module-2-digital-twin/
- [x] T002 Verify Docusaurus build process works with new directory structure

## Phase 2: Foundational Tasks

### Docusaurus Configuration Updates

- [x] T003 Update docusaurus.config.js to include navigation for Module 2
- [x] T004 Update sidebars.js to include Module 2 navigation structure
- [x] T005 [P] Create placeholder content files for all 3 chapters
- [x] T006 Verify Docusaurus build works with new configuration

## Phase 3: User Story 1 - Physics Simulation in Gazebo (Priority: P1)

### Goal
AI students and developers can understand and practice physics simulation in Gazebo to model robot behavior in realistic environments. This includes simulating gravity, collisions, and physical interactions between robots and their environment.

### Independent Test Criteria
Students can complete physics simulation exercises by creating basic Gazebo environments with gravity, collision objects, and simple robot models. This delivers immediate value by allowing them to observe how robots behave in physically accurate simulations.

### Tasks

- [x] T007 [US1] Create comprehensive content for physics-simulation-gazebo.md covering gravity simulation
- [x] T008 [P] [US1] Add collision detection content to physics-simulation-gazebo.md
- [x] T009 [P] [US1] Document joint dynamics and physical interactions in physics-simulation-gazebo.md
- [x] T010 [P] [US1] Create practical examples section for Gazebo physics in physics-simulation-gazebo.md
- [x] T011 [P] [US1] Add troubleshooting section for common Gazebo physics issues
- [x] T012 [P] [US1] Include configuration file examples (SDF/URDF) in physics-simulation-gazebo.md
- [x] T013 [P] [US1] Add step-by-step tutorials for basic physics simulation
- [x] T014 [US1] Update navigation links in sidebar for physics simulation chapter
- [x] T015 [US1] Add cross-references to related topics in physics-simulation-gazebo.md
- [x] T016 [US1] Verify Docusaurus build with physics simulation content
- [x] T017 [US1] Test navigation and content readability for physics simulation chapter

## Phase 4: User Story 2 - High-Fidelity Rendering in Unity (Priority: P2)

### Goal
AI students and developers can create high-fidelity visual environments in Unity to visualize robot behavior and human-robot interactions. This includes creating realistic environments and visualizing complex interactions.

### Independent Test Criteria
Students can create visually rich environments in Unity with realistic lighting, textures, and rendering that accurately represent the robot and its surroundings.

### Tasks

- [ ] T018 [US2] Create comprehensive content for unity-rendering.md covering Unity setup for robotics
- [ ] T019 [P] [US2] Document Unity-ROS bridge integration in unity-rendering.md
- [ ] T020 [P] [US2] Add high-fidelity rendering techniques to unity-rendering.md
- [ ] T021 [P] [US2] Create human-robot interaction scenarios content in unity-rendering.md
- [ ] T022 [P] [US2] Add lighting and material examples to unity-rendering.md
- [ ] T023 [P] [US2] Include Unity scene creation tutorials in unity-rendering.md
- [ ] T024 [P] [US2] Document performance optimization for Unity rendering
- [ ] T025 [US2] Update navigation links in sidebar for Unity rendering chapter
- [ ] T026 [US2] Add cross-references to related topics in unity-rendering.md
- [ ] T027 [US2] Verify Docusaurus build with Unity rendering content
- [ ] T028 [US2] Test navigation and content readability for Unity rendering chapter

## Phase 5: User Story 3 - Sensor Simulation Integration (Priority: P3)

### Goal
AI students and developers can simulate various sensors (LiDAR, Depth Cameras, IMUs) in both Gazebo and Unity environments to understand how robots perceive their world and make decisions based on sensor data.

### Independent Test Criteria
Students can configure and test simulated sensors that produce realistic data streams matching real-world sensor outputs, allowing them to develop perception algorithms.

### Tasks

- [ ] T029 [US3] Create comprehensive content for sensor-simulation.md covering LiDAR simulation
- [ ] T030 [P] [US3] Add Depth Camera simulation content to sensor-simulation.md
- [ ] T031 [P] [US3] Document IMU simulation in sensor-simulation.md
- [ ] T032 [P] [US3] Create sensor integration examples with robot models in sensor-simulation.md
- [ ] T033 [P] [US3] Add sensor data analysis and visualization tools to sensor-simulation.md
- [ ] T034 [P] [US3] Include sensor fusion concepts in sensor-simulation.md
- [ ] T035 [P] [US3] Document sensor configuration best practices in sensor-simulation.md
- [ ] T036 [P] [US3] Add troubleshooting for sensor simulation issues in sensor-simulation.md
- [ ] T037 [US3] Update navigation links in sidebar for sensor simulation chapter
- [ ] T038 [US3] Add cross-references to related topics in sensor-simulation.md
- [ ] T039 [US3] Verify Docusaurus build with sensor simulation content
- [ ] T040 [US3] Test navigation and content readability for sensor simulation chapter

## Success Criteria Verification

- [ ] SC-001: Students can create a basic Gazebo physics simulation with gravity and collision detection in under 30 minutes (verifiable through US1 content)
- [ ] SC-002: Simulated environments accurately represent physical properties with less than 5% deviation from expected values (verifiable through US1 content)
- [ ] SC-003: Students can successfully configure and test at least 3 different sensor types (LiDAR, Depth Camera, IMU) in simulation environments (verifiable through US3 content)
- [ ] SC-004: 90% of students successfully complete the digital twin simulation exercises without requiring additional support (verifiable through complete module)
- [ ] SC-005: Simulation environments run at minimum 30 FPS for basic scenarios with up to 5 robots (addressed through performance guidelines)
- [ ] SC-006: Sensor simulation data matches expected real-world patterns with at least 95% accuracy (verifiable through US3 content)
- [ ] SC-007: Students can transition from Gazebo physics simulation to Unity rendering within 2 hours of instruction (verifiable through US1 and US2 content)
